title: Boechera
text:
Boechera (rockcress) is a <a href="genus">genus</a> of the family <a href="Brassicaceae">Brassicaceae</a>. It was named after the <a href="Denmark">Danish</a> botanist <a href="Tyge%20W.%20B%C3%B6cher">Tyge W. Böcher</a> (1909–1983), who was known for his research in alpine plants, including the mustards "<a href="Draba">Draba</a>" and "Boechera holboellii". According to recent molecular-based studies, "Boechera" is closely related to the genus "<a href="Arabidopsis">Arabidopsis</a>" which also includes the widely known model plant "<a href="Arabidopsis%20thaliana">Arabidopsis thaliana</a>".
Until recently, members of this genus were included in the genus "<a href="Arabis">Arabis</a>", but have been separated from that genus based on recent <a href="genetics">genetic</a> and cytological data. Unlike the genus "Arabis" (x=8) "Boechera" has a base chromosome number of x=7. Many taxa are <a href="triploid">triploid</a>. "Boechera" is a primarily North American genus, most diverse in the western <a href="United%20States">United States</a>, and its distribution range also includes <a href="Greenland">Greenland</a> and the Russian Far East. The genus is poorly known, and species within are difficult to separate morphologically though some clearly distinct species are known.
Most members of the genus are <a href="perennial%20plant">perennial plant</a>s with pubescent leaves with stellate <a href="trichomes">trichomes</a>, narrow curving fruits, and small white to purple <a href="flower">flower</a>s in elongated <a href="raceme">raceme</a>s. Relationships within the genus are unclear, and some eastern North American species, including "<a href="Boechera%20laevigata">Boechera laevigata</a>", may belong to a <a href="clade">clade</a> distinct from the rest of the genus.
A very interesting feature of many species of the genus is <a href="asexual%20reproduction">asexual reproduction</a>, a process known as <a href="apomixis">apomixis</a>. <a href="Microsatellite%20%28genetics%29">Microsatellite</a> data has revealed that some of the apomictic lineages are <a href="Hybrid%20%28biology%29">hybrids</a> between two or more <a href="Plant%20sexuality">sexual</a> parents.
Ecology.
Species in this genus are one of the main food sources for the caterpillars of the butterfly "<a href="Pieris%20oleracea">Pieris oleracea</a>."
